description: From growl +‎ -er. Sense "jug" is 19th century American slang, of uncertain origin.

entries.meaning: A person, creature or thing that growls.
(historical, slang) A horse-drawn cab with four wheels.
examples: Lew pulled his socks from a jacket pocket, grabbed his own shoes, and together they proceeded to the street and into a growler, and were off.

entries.meaning: A small iceberg or ice floe which is barely visible over the surface of the water.
examples: A great ‘growler’ iceberg was sighted this afternoon at a distance of approximately half a mile; the size of a large London house, more or less.

entries.meaning: (informal, Canada, US, Australia) A kind of jug used to carry beer (in current usage, a 2-liter or 64-ounce container with or without a handle; sometimes extended to similarly shaped 32-ounce jug, but not bottles).
examples: […]  their favoring breeze has the stink of nickel whiskey on its breath, and their sea is a growler of lager and ale  […]
Now, on first impression, a pork pie - or a ‘growler’ if you're from Yorkshire - looks like a delicious snack.
On our first meeting he'd asked me if I dyed my hair. I told him I did and his follow up[sic] question had been the much under rated[sic], "What colour's your growler then?"

entries.meaning: (US, dialect) A fish of the perch family, abundant in North American rivers, so named from the sound it emits.
A device for checking electrical equipment for short circuits etc.
examples: Includes voltmeters, ammeters, circuit testers, armature tester (external growler), field tester, (internal growler), coil and condenser tester, etc.
